steps.title: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C).
steps.content: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C). Before you do anything else, switch on your oven. Let it warm up to 350 °F (177 °C) while you prepare your drumsticks. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Peel back the skin.
steps.content: Peel back the skin. Grip the skin near the bone and gently peel it toward the top of the drumstick. Don't pull it off entirely; just peel it back, so you can tuck butter and seasonings underneath. [2] X Research source Turkey drumsticks are much larger than chicken drumsticks, so you'll only need 1 per person (2 at most).

steps.title: Rub 1 tablespoon (14 g) of butter over the meat of each drumstick.
steps.content: Rub 1 tablespoon (14 g) of butter over the meat of each drumstick. This will keep the meat moist while the drumsticks bake. For larger drumsticks, you can use up to 3 tablespoons (42 g) of butter. [4] X Research source To make the butter easier to spread, bring it to room temperature before applying it to the turkey. Use olive oil in place of butter if you're calorie conscious.

steps.title: Season the turkey.
steps.content: Season the turkey. With the skin still pulled down, sprinkle salt and pepper all over the turkey legs. For more flavor, try rubbing a tablespoon (about 2-4 g) of chopped herbs onto the buttered turkey meat while the skins are still pulled back. Rosemary, thyme, and sage make great seasonings for turkey.

steps.title: Pull the skin over the meat and rub it with butter.
steps.content: Pull the skin over the meat and rub it with butter. Stretch the skin back over the meat and rub another 1-3 tablespoons (14-42 g) of butter over the skin of the turkey. This will help the skin crisp up as it bakes.

steps.title: Sprinkle the skin with salt and pepper.
steps.content: Sprinkle the skin with salt and pepper. Use a liberal amount of both salt and pepper to bring out the best in the turkey's flavor.

steps.title: Lay the turkey legs in a roasting pan.
steps.content: Lay the turkey legs in a roasting pan. Use a pan large enough to easily hold all of the legs with no overlap. If you want to catch the drippings, use a metal roasting rack over a drip pan.

steps.title: Bake the turkey drumsticks for 90 minutes.
steps.content: Bake the turkey drumsticks for 90 minutes. Place them in the preheated oven for 45 minutes. Turn them over and cook them for another 45 minutes. Insert a meat thermometer into the thickest part of the meat. They are ready when the internal temperature reaches 165 °F (74 °C). [5] X Trustworthy Source Food Safety and Inspection Service of the USDA Food safety information provided by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Go to source To ensure that the turkey stays juicy, you can baste it every 20 minutes with a turkey baster or spoon. Use the drippings as your basting liquid, or baste with extra melted butter. Larger drumsticks may take a total of 2 hours to finish cooking.

steps.title: Let the meat rest for 15 minutes before serving.
steps.content: Let the meat rest for 15 minutes before serving. This gives the juices time to reabsorb into the flesh, making the meat juicy. Serve whole or remove the meat from the bone.

steps.title: Heat your gas or charcoal grill to medium heat.
steps.content: Heat your gas or charcoal grill to medium heat. Turkey drumsticks require almost an hour on the grill, and it's important to maintain a steady heat of about 300 °F (149 °C) so they don't burn or end up undercooked. [6] X Research source Use a grill thermometer to test the heat of your grill.

steps.title: Season your turkey drumsticks.
steps.content: Season your turkey drumsticks. Sprinkle the meat all over with salt and pepper. If you want to add spices and other seasonings, spread mixed spices all over each drumstick to coat the skin. Try these delicious combinations: For hot and spicy drumsticks: combine 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) cayenne pepper, 1/2 teaspoon (1.5 g) garlic powder, 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) black pepper, and 1/2 teaspoon (3 g) salt For herb-encrusted drumsticks: combine 1/2 teaspoon (.4 g) dried basil, 1/2 teaspoon (.7 g) dried thyme, 1/2 teaspoon (1.5 g) garlic powder, and 1/2 teaspoon (3 g) salt

steps.title: Cook the drumsticks in indirect heat for 1 hour.
steps.content: Cook the drumsticks in indirect heat for 1 hour. Lay them on a part of the grill that isn't getting a stream of direct heat, since this will cook them too quickly.

steps.title: Turn the drumsticks every 10 minutes.
steps.content: Turn the drumsticks every 10 minutes. This will ensure they cook evenly on all sides. Keep going as each side turns golden brown and crispy. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Test the internal temperature of the drumsticks.
steps.content: Test the internal temperature of the drumsticks. Insert a meat thermometer into the thickest part of the meat. The drumsticks are ready when the internal temperature reaches 180 °F (82 °C).

steps.title: Remove the skin from the drumsticks.
steps.content: Remove the skin from the drumsticks. Use as many drumsticks as you can fit in your slow cooker. Since the skin won't get crispy in the slow cooker, it's best to remove it before cooking.

steps.title: Season the meat with salt and pepper to taste.
steps.content: Season the meat with salt and pepper to taste. Sprinkle a generous amount of salt and pepper on each of the drumsticks to enhance their flavor as they cook.

steps.title: Place your drumsticks into your slow cooker.
steps.content: Place your drumsticks into your slow cooker. Since the drumsticks are so large, you might have trouble fitting more than 2. You can lop off the ends of the bones if necessary.

steps.title: Cover the drumsticks with chicken broth.
steps.content: Cover the drumsticks with chicken broth. The liquid is necessary to flavor the turkey and help it cook evenly and slowly in the slow cooker. Fill up the slow cooker until the turkey legs are completely submerged. [8] X Research source For extra flavor, add a packet of onion soup mix to the pot. Or add the following: 1 teaspoon (6 g) salt, 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) pepper, and 1 teaspoon (3 g) garlic powder.

steps.title: Cover the slow cooker and cook on low heat for 8 to 9 hours.
steps.content: Cover the slow cooker and cook on low heat for 8 to 9 hours. Plan ahead so you can time the drumsticks to be ready for your dinnertime.

steps.title: Let the drumsticks cool.
steps.content: Let the drumsticks cool. Transfer the drumsticks to a plate or other heat-proof surface and allow them to cool for 5 to 10 minutes.

steps.title: Pull the meat off the bones.
steps.content: Pull the meat off the bones. The turkey meat is delicious served with your favorite sauce over noodles or rice. You can also add it to a casserole or soup.

steps.title: Place the turkey legs in a large stockpot.
steps.content: Place the turkey legs in a large stockpot. Make sure it's big enough to comfortably hold all of the drumsticks you want to cook.

steps.title: Cover the drumsticks with water or chicken broth.
steps.content: Cover the drumsticks with water or chicken broth. Fill the pot to within a few inches of the top of the rim, rather than right up to the edge. The drumsticks should be completely submerged. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Season the water or broth.
steps.content: Season the water or broth. Add a teaspoon (6 g) of salt, a half teaspoon (1 g) of pepper, and any other seasonings you desire. The seasoned water will penetrate the turkey meat to flavor it as it cooks.

steps.title: Boil the turkey legs for about 60 minutes.
steps.content: Boil the turkey legs for about 60 minutes. Bring the liquid to a rolling boil, then reduce it slightly to a low boil that won't splash. After an hour, insert a meat thermometer into the thickest part of the meat. The turkey legs are ready when the internal temperature reaches 180 °F (82 °C). [10] X Research source

steps.title: Drain the turkey legs and let them cool.
steps.content: Drain the turkey legs and let them cool. Pour them over a colander to drain out the water, then let the meat cool for about 10 minutes before you try to handle it.

steps.title: Remove the skin and pick off the meat.
steps.content: Remove the skin and pick off the meat. Be careful to make sure small bones are removed. Use the meat to make barbecue, soup, or a casserole.
